data.description: Performance degradation of I/O when commands timeout due to faulty storage hardware
data.summary:
"Abort Command Issued" messages are being detected, which are indicative of a storage area network (SAN) or hardware error.

Verify if there are any issues present from the FC switch, FC cabling, zoning, or storage array. Red Hat recommends that you contact the storage vendor to review the issue encountered.
data.generic:
"Abort Command Issued" messages are being detected, which are indicative of a storage area network (SAN) or hardware error.

Verify if there are any issues present from the FC switch, FC cabling, zoning, or storage array. Red Hat recommends that you contact the storage vendor to review the issue encountered.
data.reason:
This host has encountered **{{=pydata.total_aborts}}** occurrences of *Abort command issued* in /var/log/messages, including {{?pydata.abort_groups > 1}}multiple occurrences{{??}}1 occurrence{{?}} of 10 or more abort commands occurring within a period of an hour.  

*Abort command issued* messages indicate an error condition being returned from the SAN.

An example abort command that is displayed in /var/log/messages: 

**{{=pydata.example_abort}}**

resolution_set.resolution:
Red Hat recommends that you verify if there are any issues present from the FC switch, FC cabling, zoning, or storage array and contact the storage vendor to review the switch logs to verify if there are any error counters, CRC errors in FC switch logs to solve this issue.


After applying the remediation, refresh the results of Advisor analysis by running the `insights-client` command on the system. 
~~~ 
# insights-client 
~~~

data.description: The abrtd process causes a high CPU usage due to a known bug
data.summary: The `abrtd` process consumes a high CPU due to a known bug in the `abrt` package.
data.generic: The `abrtd` process consumes a high CPU due to a known bug in the `abrt` package.
data.reason: The host is running with **{{=pydata.pkg}}** installed. The CPU usage of the `abrtd` process is **{{=pydata.cpu_usage}}**.
data.more_info: Refer to bug [abrtd process consumes 100% of one core](https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1655241) for more details.

resolution_set.resolution:
Red Hat recommends that you perform the following steps:

{{?pydata.cur_lock && pydata.rcm_locks}}
* Unset the release lock.
  ~~~
  # subscription-manager release --unset
  ~~~
{{?}}

{{?pydata.no_base &&
  (pydata.cur_lock==null || (pydata.cur_lock && pydata.rcm_locks))}}
* Enable the RHEL base repo:
  ~~~
  # subscription-manager repos --enable={{=pydata.no_base}}
  ~~~
  Note: To fix the issue in the base channel, you have to enable the base channel at first.
{{?}}

{{?pydata.cur_lock && pydata.req_repos && pydata.rcm_locks==null}}
* {{?Object.keys(pydata.req_repos).length > 1}}Enable one of the following channels{{??}}Enable the following channel{{?}}:
  ~~~
  {{~pydata.req_repos:e}}# subscription-manager repos --enable={{=e}}
  {{~}}
  ~~~
  Note: Red Hat only provides the resolution in the required channel{{?Object.keys(pydata.req_repos).length > 1}}s{{?}}. 
{{?}}
* Upgrade the `abrt` package:
  ~~~
  # yum update abrt
  ~~~

**Workaround**, if upgrading the abrt package is not an option, please restart the `abrtd` service:
~~~
# systemctl restart abrtd.service
~~~


After applying the remediation, refresh the results of Advisor analysis by running the `insights-client` command on the system. 
~~~ 
# insights-client 
~~~

data.description: D-Bus timeout occurs when there are a large number of existing abrt crash directories
data.summary: Due to **D-Bus** is not well-suited for data-plane transmissions, a large number of existing crashes will typically result in metadata being sent for some ABRT utilities, which can take long enough to cause timeouts and service hang.
data.generic: Due to **D-Bus** is not well-suited for data-plane transmissions, a large number of existing crashes will typically result in metadata being sent for some ABRT utilities, which can take long enough to cause timeouts and service hang.
data.reason: This system is running **{{=pydata.abrt_dbus}}**. There are **{{=pydata.too_many_problems}}** abrt crash directories existing. Due to D-Bus not well-suited for data-plane transmissions, it is possible that abrt utilities using D-Bus will hang when there are a large number of existing abrt crashes.

resolution_set.resolution:
Red Hat recommends that you clear abrt crash directories:
~~~
# abrt-cli remove /var/spool/abrt/*
~~~


After applying the remediation, refresh the results of Advisor analysis by running the `insights-client` command on the system. 
~~~ 
# insights-client 
~~~

data.description: AD users fail to log in due to a known issue in SSSD
data.summary:
Due to a known bug in the `sssd` rpm package, AD users can fail to login with 
the error message **"pam_sss(pfmenu:auth): Request to sssd failed. Device or 
resource busy."** printed in the secure log.
data.generic:
Due to a known bug in the `sssd` rpm package, AD users can fail to login with 
the error message **"pam_sss(pfmenu:auth): Request to sssd failed. Device or 
resource busy."** printed in the secure log.
